questions.text: All are side effects of cocaine toxicity except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bradycardia Cocaine causes tachycardia and not bradycardia.

Highyeild:

COCAINE - Obtained from leaves of Erythroxylon Coca. Slang names : White lady, Coke, Cadillac, Snow Cigarettes with cocaine called crack Cocaine leaves contain < 2% of cocaine→ Treated with H2SO4 → Cocaine sulfate → Treated with HCl→ Cocaine Hydrochloride →Cocaine hydrochloride contains 90% of cocaine →Used for snorting and injections Cocaine hydrochloride again treated with baking soda → crack → smoke Most Common usage – snorting Actions Local Anesthetic Powerful CNS depressant – for a short time Rush followed by depression. Signs and symptoms Acute addiction: Stage of early stimulation- euphoria, dry mouth,tachycardia,numb mouth. Stage of advanced stimulation- hallucination, hyperthermia (cocaine fever), convulsions. Stage of depression- Muscle paralysis, coma, death. Treatment : Amyl Nitrate Chronic Addiction- Cocainism Cocainophagia Cocainomana Black discoloration of teeth & tongue Painless perforation of Nasal septum Magnum symptoms – also called cocaine bugs /formication/Tactile Hallucination → Bugs / Insects / Sand particles crawling beneath skin→ Scratching → Multiple scratch marks + →Bruxism → Grinding of teeth. Medico Legal Importance- Cocaine – 2nd most commonly used illicit drug. Applied on glans penis to increase duration of coitus. Prostitutes inject into vagina for local construction Cocaine + Heroine → I.V – speedball → smoke – moon rock

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. hyperthermia- called as cocaine fever seen in Stage of advanced stimulation Option C. Myocardial infarction-risk is maximum in the initial 1 hour of cocaine use. Option D. Agitation- seen in the stimulation stage of cocaine use.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: During autopsy the doctor noticed changes. True regarding these changes?

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with lighting cases.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Due to Sulf Methemoglobin Marbling is shown in the image. Image shows an irregular tortuous network of discolored veins . Reddish brown / greenish discolored veins Look like branches of a tree / marbled appearance . These are seen in the roots of limbs,abdomen and flanks . Marbling develops due to the delineation of the vasculature as a result of the reaction of hydrogen sulfide produced by bacteria with hemoglobin from the lysis of erythrocytes forming sulfa methemoglobin bluish green in color. It appears within 36 hours of death. It is well established by 36 to 48 hours.

Highyeild:

Decomposition/putrefaction: Colour changes: The earliest sign of decomposition is greenish discoloration of the body, seen first in the right iliac fossa externally and under the liver internally ( because in caecum , the contents are more liquid and are full of bacteria.) . In these areas, It appears in 12-18 hours, and slowly spread on whole body in 24-48 hr. greenish discoloration is due to formation of Sulph meth haemoglobin. Hb→ meth Hb→ +H2S→ Sulph meth haemoglobin. Later colour may change to purple, brown, bluish green or even almost black ( colour black is due to ferric sulphide.) The colouring matter (Hb) dissociates from the B.C. and the colour is taken up by the blood vessels, which are seen as prominent lines having purple, green or brown colour, especially on shoulders, axilla & Inguinal area. This change results in 24-48 hr , and is labelled as

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Seen in 24 hours - this is seen after 24 hr. Option C. It is non bacterial- It is a sign of decomposition, which is bacterial. Option D. It is associated with lighting cases-Filigree burns is associated with lighting cases, which do not lie along veins and are thin as compared to M arbling.

questions.text: The active principle of this poison?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bhilawanol Seeds of Semecarpus anacardium , often called as marking nuts is shown in the image.Its active principles include bhilawanol among the given options.

Highyeild:

Bhilawanol- It is closely related to the cashew. Its active principles include anacardic acid, cardol, catechol, anacardoside, fixed oil, semecarpol, bhilawanol, bioflavonoids, biflavones, etc. If consumed in very large quantities, it is said to induce However, in moderation it is considered good for the female reproductive system. The fruits are traditionally used for astringent, rubefacient, counter irritant and aphrodisiac Juice of the fruit pericarp is used for marking cotton clothes. Apart from its medicinal properties, it is also poisonous without any purification and the oil from its seeds can give blisters and painful wounds . ( false bruises )

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Abrin - Abrin is the active principle of Abrus precatorius (ratti) which is also used to make Option B. Ricin-Ricin is the active principle of Ricinus communis (castor oil plant). Option C. Crotin- Crotin is the active principle of Croton tiglium ( jamalgota ).

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A boy ate some fruit and became irritable, disoriented, hallucinated with high fever. Identify the poison with an antidote?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Datura, physostigmine irritable, disoriented, hallucinated with high fever (antimuscarinic poison) after having a fruit is suggestive of dhatura poisoning . An appropriate antidote for datura is Acetylcholinesterase Inhibitor Physostigmine.

Highyeild:

DHATURA - All parts of the plant are poisonous, particularly fruits and seeds. Fruit has got multiple spikes, so it is called ThornApple Fruit contains about 500 seeds and they resemble chili seeds. Active principle Hyoscine – Scopolamine Hyoscyamine Atropine Clinical features -Ds Delirium Diplopia Dimness of vision Dilatation of pupil Dryness of mouth Dysphagia Dysphonia Dilatation of cutaneous vessels Flushing of face Drunken gait Death due to Resp. failure Raised body temperature Constipation Urinary retention Associated with incoherent talks and purposeless movements → CARPHOLOGIA Pin rolling Picking up bed clothes Pulling imaginary thread – finger tips Trying to thread imaginary needle Fatal Dose: 100 – 125 seeds Fatal period : 24hours Treatment Specific Antidote - physostigmine Medicolegal Importance- Stupefying poison – Rape, Robbery, Kidnap Roadside poison

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime-Pralidoxime is used in organophosphorus poison. Option C. Yellow oleander, pralidoxime and Option D. Yellow oleander, digoxin- Yellow oleander roots are poisonous, not fruit. Patients will present with cardiac symptoms, not antimuscarinic symptoms.

Extraedge:

Acts done under involuntary toxication are not held responsible under Sec.85 IPC

Table:

#MANTRA Poisoning Antidote Organophosphorus and carbamate Atropine (atropine is not used for organochlorine poisoning only organophosphorus) Atropine Physostigmine Opioids Naloxone (Intravenous) Valproate hyperammonemia Carnitine Beta blocker Glucagon Calcium channel blocker Calcium gluconate MgSO4 toxicity Calcium gluconate Na channel blocking drugs Na bicarbonate Dig oxin Dig ibind/ Digi fab Paracetamol N-Acetyl cysteine Neuroleptic Malignant syndrome Dantrolene sodium (DOC) Specific antidote if NMS due to D2 blockade-Bromocriptine Drug-induced dystonia Central anticholinergic Benzhexol Benztropine Biperiden 1st generation antihistamines Promethazine Diphenhydramine Tricyclic antidepressants NaHCO3 Sulfonylurea induced hypoglycemia Octreotide Cyanide Hydroxocobalamin Heparin.LMWH Protamine sulfate Warfarin Vitamin K Da bigatran Idarucizumab Rivaro xa b an Ap i xa ban(direct Xa inhibitor) And xa net alfa Fibrinolytic drug overdose Epsilon amino caproic acid, tranexamic acid Alco h ol , Metha n ol , Ethylene gly c ol Fomepiz ole Benzodia zep ines , Z drugs, Beta carboline Fluma ze nil Methotrexate Folinic acid/Leucovorin/Citrovorin Glucarpidase (preferred in renal failure) Methemoglobinemia Methylene blue Isoniazid induced seizure Pyridoxine Iron Acute iron poisoning- Desferioxamine Chronic iron overload- Deferiprone Deferasirox Copper Penicillamine Arsenic/lead/mercury BAL

questions.text: Image of a wound shown. Identify?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Incised looking lacerated Incised looking lacerated wound- Wound without a regular elliptical margin , but looking clean cut involving Forehead point towards Incised looking lacerated wound.

Highyeild:

Split Laceration- Also called as incised looking laceration Split lacerations are caused by blunt force splitting the thickness of the skin most frequently when the skin and soft tissues are crushed between impacting force and underlying bone. These types of lacerations are usually found in body parts with underlying bones without much tissue in between. Common sites include – scalp , face, shin etc. Due to splitting of skin these lacerations appear like incised wounds.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B.Lacerated looking incised wounds- are seen on parts of the body having loose skins g. scrotum,axilla. Option C.Incised wound- will have a regular elliptical margin. Option D. Contusion- will have discolouration and swelling of skin.

Table:

#MANTRA CRITERIA SPLIT LACERATION INCISED WOUND Margins Ragged Clean cut Abrasions & contusion along margin Present Absent Tissue bridges → Muscle → Tendon →Nerve → Vessel Crushed Clean out Haemorrhage Less Profuse Hair Crushed & driven into Injury Cut

questions.text: Lawyer asks the witness "did u see B killing A" witness answers yes. What is the type of examination?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cross examination Leading questions can only be asked during cross-examination and not during examination-in-chief or re-examination unless and until the court allows.

Highyeild:

Sec. 141 IEA – Defines leading Questions Sec. 142 IEA – It says where leading questions are not allowed in which phase of trial. Sec. 143 IEA – Where leading questions are allowed. Leading questions are allowed in cross examination Exception is the leading question allowed in chief examination when the witness becomes hostile. Legal procedure - Leading Questions can be put by Judge in any part of the trial . In Reexamination, the leading questions are absolutely not allowed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Examination in Chief - Examination in chief is the first examination of witnesses after the oath . It is the state in which a party called a witness to examine him in chief for the purpose of eliciting from the witness all the material facts within his knowledge which tend to prove the party's case. It is also known as Direct Examination. Option B. Direct Examination - The direct examination or examination-in-chief is one stage in the process of adducing evidence from witnesses in a court of law. Direct examination is the questioning of a witness by the lawyer/side/party that called such witness in a trial. Option D.Re direct examination- It is conducted by the counsel who has called the doctor and is to clarify any discrepancies that have arisen during cross examination.

Extraedge:

Procedure of the court- Summon Oath administration Recording of evidence Examination in chief Cross examination Re-examination Court questions

questions.text: The phenomenon seen in the image is due to?
questions.correct_answer: C. Immersion in water for 36 hrs
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immersion in water for 36 hrs Given image shows washerwoman’s skin due to maceration of the skin due to prolonged immersion in water.

Highyeild:

Drowning- Post – Mortem findings - External Internal 1. External- Froth : White lathery copious from mouth & nostrils Reappears on wiping Do not readily collapse when touched by sharp tip as it is lined by surfactant As the water enters the air passage→Water stimulates mucosal lining of bronchi & trachea produces large amounts of mucus. Water irritates alveolar lining cells → large amount of surfactant→ Violent entry of air – churns water mucus and surfactant → froth Cadaveric spasm Cutis Anserina : Goose flesh, goose skin Due to contraction of arrector pili muscles – erection of hairs on the skin surface. Washerman’s /Washerwoman's hands / foot: Skin of palms and soles -Sodden, bleached wrinkled Internal- Lungs- Ballooning of lungs Lungs are voluminous, distended, bulge out open opening sternum Rib Marking – grooves on lateral surface of lungs b.Emphysema Aquosum Entry of water into tissue / parenchyma of lungs due to rupture of alveolar walls Seen in 80% of cases Importance: seen in AM drowning Oedema Aquosum Passive entry of water into lungs without formation of froth Seen in unconscious person in water d . Paultauf’s Hemorrhages Multiple shining, bluish or bluish red haemorrhagic spots seen sub-pleurally in lower lobe of lungs Intrapulmonary hemorrhages produced due to rupture of alveolar walls. Stomach - In 70% cases, water seen in stomach Chemical and microscopic nature of stomach is same as chemical and microscopic nature of the medium in which body was found Stomach containing unpalatable / undrinkable water suggestive of antemortem drowning Water in Intestine -Seen in 20% of cases Suggestive of antemortem drowning Hemorrhages in middle ear, mastoid process and temporal bone Gettler’s test - Chloride concentration is measured on Right and Left side of heart In fresh water drowning – Left side receives hyper diluted blood and so chloride content is less on the left side. In sea water – Left side receives hyper concentrated blood, so chloride content will be more on Left side Any difference in chloride levels between Right and Left side of heart to the extent of 25% suggesting of antemortem drowning Diatom Test - Diatoms are unicellular algae Contain Diatomic – brown pigment Diatoms contain thick silicacious cell wall which are highly resistant to Principle - Person if alive in water→Inhales Diatoms in lungs→Heart → pumped to peripheral organs→Detection of diatoms in peripheral organ indicates AM drowning Best specimen - Bone Marrow →Femur →Sternum Tests → Acid digestion test Incineration test Direct detection from lung

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.Torture in hot water- will show scald injury. Option B.Post- mortem hanging- will have features of dragging of dead body, absence of ligature fibers on hand of dead. Option D.Colliquative liquefaction- is a microscopic finding , characterized by partial or complete dissolution of dead tissue and transformation into a liquid.

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins of the same gestational age. The father alleged that the children do not belong to him. DNA test reveals that one of the twin children belongs to him, while the other one does not. What is the condition called:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superfecundation Twins with different father suggests that two different ova are fertilized by two different sperm in more than one act of coitus during the same cycle seen in Superfecundation.

Highyeild:

Superfecundation (1 cycle, 2 oocytes): occurs when two different ova are fertilized by two different sperm in more than one act of coitus during the same cycle. They are of the same gestational age. Superfetation (2 cycles, 2 oocytes) :occurs when a second fertilized ovum implants in a uterus already containing a pregnancy of at least 1 month. Superfetation has been suggested in some cases in which the twins are markedly discordant for birth weight, supposedly due to different gestational ages. Suppositious child : is a spurious child produced for inheritance claims or other malicious reasons . Posthumous child : is a child born after the death of the father . To be legitimate the child should be born within 280 days of the death of the father. Pseudocyesis/ spurious pregnancy/ Phantom pregnancy/False pregnancy :Intense desire for pregnancy by a married person → starts experiencing symptoms suggestive of pregnancy (Amenorrhoea, Bloating of abdomen , quickening movements).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B.Supposititious child- any malicious reason not mentioned in the question. Option C.Superfetation- gestational age of twins will be Option D.Posthumous child - is born after the death of the father.
